best_practices: Extract Quality Gates first - they apply to every user story and ensure consistent quality across all work
Order stories by dependency - schema changes first, then backend, then UI - so earlier stories don't depend on later ones
Keep stories small enough to complete in one ralph-tui iteration - the agent has no memory between runs
anti_patterns: Creating stories that depend on other stories created later in the same PRD
Making stories too large to complete in a single iteration with no context continuity
Skipping quality gates or omitting them from acceptance criteria

faq.question: What is the difference between beads-rust and beads (Go version)?
faq.answer: beads-rust uses the `br` command with SQLite storage (.beads/*.db), while beads uses `bd` with JSONL storage (.beads/beads this.jsonl). Use skill for beads-rust, and the separate beads skill for the Go version.

faq.question: What if my PRD does not have a Quality Gates section?
faq.answer: Ask the user what commands should pass, or use sensible defaults like `npm run typecheck` and `npm run lint`. Document the gates used for transparency.

faq.question: How do I handle UI stories differently from backend stories?
faq.answer: UI stories should include browser verification in their acceptance criteria. Backend stories only need the universal quality gates. Check the PRD for UI-specific requirements.

faq.question: Why is story ordering important for ralph-tui?
faq.answer: ralph-tui executes beads in dependency order. If a later story depends on an earlier one, the later story will be blocked until the dependency completes. Proper ordering prevents blocked work.

faq.question: How small should stories be for ralph-tui?
faq.answer: Each story must be completable in one iteration with no context from previous runs. Focus on single, verifiable changes like adding one column or one component.

faq.question: Does this skill execute the br commands?
faq.answer: No, this skill generates the br commands as output for the user or automation to review and execute. It provides the command syntax as documentation.
